paragraphs.name: 219c
paragraphs.text: Annotate Once: AngularDart

paragraphs.name: 0b92
paragraphs.text: Introducing Component Inheritance

paragraphs.name: 50e5
paragraphs.text: AngularDart allows developers to create components and directives by annotating class definitions with metadata. This metadata instructs the compiler to generate code necessary for dependency injection, template construction, data binding, and more.

paragraphs.name: f1e8
paragraphs.text: An example of metadata used to declare a simple component.

paragraphs.name: a47a
paragraphs.text: Until recently, the AngularDart compiler did not process metadata on supertypes. This meant sharing common functionality between different components and directives via inheritance required redeclaring all of the metadata in each class.

paragraphs.name: 9f88
paragraphs.text: Let’s see what this pattern looked like.

paragraphs.name: 0c05
paragraphs.text: Throughout this article, the following example will be revisited to demonstrate the benefits of metadata inheritance. This is a simplified example drawn from the official Material Design components for AngularDart used at Google.

paragraphs.name: 30dc
paragraphs.text: A simple directive that adds button functionality to its host element.

paragraphs.name: 5a89
paragraphs.text: Here we have a simple directive that adds button functionality to its host element. If the host element is clicked, or focused when the enter key is pressed, it will emit an event via the trigger output. It can also be disabled to prevent emitting events. This logic can be reused to create a button component using inheritance.

paragraphs.name: b9e7
paragraphs.text: Notice the need to redeclare the input, output, and host listeners.

paragraphs.name: d3f6
paragraphs.text: Now we have a component which inherits button behavior from the directive, but notice the need to redeclare the input, output, and host listeners in the derived component annotation?

paragraphs.name: bb5c
paragraphs.text: As of version 4.0, redeclaring metadata on derived types is no longer necessary!

paragraphs.name: 0c62
paragraphs.text: The derived component now implicitly has its ancestor’s behavior.

paragraphs.name: 7aca
paragraphs.text: Now MyButtonComponent implicitly has the same input, output and host listeners as MyButtonDirective, similar to how a class normally inherits properties and methods. Now that you’ve seen a simple — and hopefully compelling — example, let’s look at what exactly is inheritable and how it works.

paragraphs.name: e5d9
paragraphs.text: What is inheritable?

paragraphs.name: f3e4
paragraphs.text: The following annotations are now inherited from all supertypes, including superclasses, interfaces, and mixins.

paragraphs.name: c601
paragraphs.text: @ContentChild / @ContentChildren

paragraphs.name: 7b2c
paragraphs.text: @HostBinding

paragraphs.name: adab
paragraphs.text: @HostListener

paragraphs.name: 8a79
paragraphs.text: @Input

paragraphs.name: aa6d
paragraphs.text: @Output
@ViewChild / @ViewChildren

paragraphs.name: dcd7
paragraphs.text: This means it’s no longer necessary to redeclare any of the above annotations in a derived class.

paragraphs.name: e414
paragraphs.text: What isn’t inheritable?

paragraphs.name: 932c
paragraphs.text: Templates, styles, and other @Directive parameters are not inherited. Only metadata that is bound to a property or method is inherited. This decision was made because derived types can override accessors and methods, referencing their original implementation via super, whereas no such mechanism exists for the values bound to other metadata.

paragraphs.name: 2e56
paragraphs.text: Inherited metadata is immutable
It’s still valid to redeclare annotations in derived types; however, modifying the inherited metadata or binding it to a different property is not permitted.

paragraphs.name: 32bf
paragraphs.text: Changing an input binding name is prohibited.

paragraphs.name: 20ef
paragraphs.text: This restriction may be lifted in the future, but for now is necessary to simplify tooling and ensure components and directives are easily substitutable.

paragraphs.name: 4a57
paragraphs.text: Metadata base types

paragraphs.name: 8dfb
paragraphs.text: An interesting consequence arises as a result of metadata inheritance: classes that are not directives or components themselves, may now be annotated to serve as base types or mixins for others. Let’s further develop our example to demonstrate.

paragraphs.name: 82ee
paragraphs.text: There’s an issue with the current button component implementation: the button isn’t focusable. This means it’s not accessible, and can’t be triggered via the key press listener. This issue is also present with the button directive if its host element isn’t focusable. We can solve this problem by making the button directive set the tabindex property on the host element.

paragraphs.name: 727d
paragraphs.text: MyButtonDirective could implement this directly, but let’s imagine we have other components that will want focusable behavior as well. Instead, we’ll create an abstract class that can be extended or mixed in by directives or components.

paragraphs.name: efd8
paragraphs.text: Allows the host element to receive keyboard focus, when not disabled.

paragraphs.name: d41e
paragraphs.text: We can now simply extend or mix in HasTabIndex to make the button directive — and consequently the derived component — focusable.

paragraphs.name: f584
paragraphs.text: The button directive — and its subtypes — are now focusable!

paragraphs.name: b399
paragraphs.text: Conclusion

paragraphs.name: a2f1
paragraphs.text: We’ve seen how inheritable metadata reduces code duplication among components and directives with shared functionality. Furthermore, it should improve readability by allowing metadata to live next to its associated field or method. Hopefully you’ll find this feature helpful in developing and maintaining your own projects.

coverImage.alt: Screenshot of a desktop with the Cursor application open

user.name: Filip Hracek
user.bio: I’m a pro­gram­ming buff with formal train­ing in jour­nal­ism. I build games, teach pro­gram­ming, explain things, and create silly soft­ware experiments.
